definitions.definition: To be in contact or connection with.
examples: The living room and dining room adjoin each other.

definitions.definition: To extend an algebraic object (e.g. a field, a ring , etc.) by adding to it an element not belonging to it and then ensuring closure , for example by also adding all finite power series of the element.
examples: The ring adjunction Q [ 2 ] {\displaystyle \mathbb {Q} [{\sqrt {2}}]} can be obtained from Q {\displaystyle \mathbb {Q} } by adjoining 2 {\displaystyle {\sqrt {2}}} to Q {\displaystyle \mathbb {Q} } .
The field adjunction Q ( π ) {\displaystyle \mathbb {Q} (\pi )} can be obtained from Q {\displaystyle \mathbb {Q} } by adjoining π {\displaystyle \pi } to Q {\displaystyle \mathbb {Q} } .
definitions.label_groups: transitive , mathematics , chiefly algebra and number theory

main_definition: ( transitive ) To be in contact or connection with.
secondary_definitions: ( transitive , mathematics , chiefly algebra and number theory ) To extend an algebraic object (e.g. a field, a ring , etc.) by adding to it an element not belonging to it and then ensuring closure , for example by also adding all finite power series of the element.
